Thomas Worthmore, a recent college graduate, pulled into a large warehouse in the center of the city darkened under the thick curtain of night. He opened the door to his brand new Porsche and calmly and coolly stepped out into a deserted gravel lot. He then began to make his way in the direction of the warehouse where a couple of semi trucks were unloading their cargo. See, Thomas worked for a big-time drug company that his father—William Worthmore—had built and run from a fairly young age. Thomas had gone off to college and gotten a degree in business logistics and finance, which put him in a position to run the drug company’s ordering of ingredients. Put simply, Thomas was the guy responsible for making sure all the proverbial trains ran on time, as well as for buying the stuff they carried.

Thomas was quite made for such work. His mother had died when he was only eight years old, and the memory of that traumatic experience—all the countless doctors and specialists who could not save her—had left Thomas cynical and jaded…borderline sociopathic, in fact. He didn’t like people much, and his wealth (more accurately, his father’s) had tragically not activated any sort of philanthropic instinct. Rather, it had left him unable to empathize with the pain of others, their sorrows, their hopes and dreams, and so forth. With that in mind, a job that required him to sit in front of a computer and crunch numbers all day made sense for him.

Physically, Thomas was a small man, only about five feet six inches tall and about 130 pounds. He had slicked back black hair and a pleasant enough face. His small stature had also reinforced his personality; it helped him learn that one needs sometimes to be ruthless to survive, be cunning, and so forth.

Thomas walked slate-faced into the bustling warehouse, past forklift operators and guys in blue work-suits going about their businesses. He spoke to no one on the way in, but he did give the occasional slight smile as he went about his destination. Everybody was nice to him; after all, Thomas was the boss’s kid. He made his way to the back of the warehouse, to the cargo that most concerned him. Turns out, a couple of the semis carried an ingredient a cold drug. Neither the drug nor the ingredient for it was particularly special, but it was still Thomas’s job to make sure everything showed up. As Thomas approached, a portly older man in a well-worn outfit saw him coming and smiled. “Good evening, Mr. Worthmore,” the man said pleasantly. Thomas smiled a little bit and responded, “How’s it going, Bill?” as he walked by the man and took a clipboard from his hands and walked with him into the semi. “Oh it’s going well sir,” Bill declared, “if I could just get the wife to leave me alone about loosing some pounds, I’d be even better,” he said as he patted his pot belly. Thomas gave no response and only looked into a couple of the boxes. He took out a small package of the ingredient to make sure it was what had been ordered. Confirming that it was, he simply signed a piece of paper on the clipboard and handed it back to Bill.

“Good,” Bill said, “everything’s in order then. Anything else I can do for you sir?” Thomas paused. “Yes, Bill,” he began, “if you could excuse me for a minute or so, that’d be great.” Bill looked confused for a moment, then nodded obediently and pleasantly, “Um, yes sir, sure, sure thing,” he said as he backed out of the semi trailer and left Thomas by himself. Alone, Thomas walked to the very back corner of the trailer and picked up two full black briefcases. Both were not huge, but they were filled to the brim with the substance Thomas had actually come for. Thomas, it turns out, had a bit of a liking for drugs—illegal ones. One of the guys at the company that supplied ingredients was Thomas’s dealer…just a couple short texts and another few thousand dollars added to an order price, and this man (name unknown) would toss some illegal drugs in with the shipment of legitimate stuff needed for the company. The trucks cam and went as always, and who would notice a couple small briefcases? No one.

Carrying his precious contraband, Thomas emerged from the truck and smiled at Bill as he made his way out of the warehouse and back to the car. He placed the briefcases in the trunk and got in to drive home. Thomas traveled once again along the darkened streets toward his big, luxurious apartment building. Suddenly, there appeared behind him an unsettling sight. “Dammit!” Thomas spat out as he saw the lights of a police car flash behind him. Irritated, he slowly pulled his car to the shoulder and turned the engine off.

He glanced in the side mirror as someone emerged from the police car…a woman, actually. She walked up to Thomas’s rolled down window, at which point he instinctively held up his license and registration. The officer shone her flashlight upon Thomas, and the lights from passing cars illuminated her own features a bit. “Mr. Worthmore,” she said, as she took his license, “you again.” Thomas looked up to see the officer. Turns out she’d stopped him before. This figure was that of Officer Brenda Nelson, and what a wonderful figure it was. She handed it to Thomas and declared, “We’ve got to stop meeting like this.” Thomas chuckled, “Well we could meet some other way. You could let me take you to dinner and…well…we could find a new use for those handcuffs of yours.” Without a smile, Nelson answered, “Just pay the damn ticket and be glad I don’t bust you for sexual harassment.” Another chuckle from Thomas. He pointed to Nelson’s bulging chest and began, “Speaking of bust…” She shook her head in disgust and turned to walk away. “Good night, Mr. Worthmore.” “It certainly is,” Thomas declared as he watched the woman’s shapely rear sway and jiggle with her steps. The first man was tall and in his mid 40's, his blonde hair and goatee were neatly trimmed, he was known only as 'Hans'. His two associates, Yevgeny and Mikhail, were both Russian, of stocky build and were obviously his bodyguards.

"Eyes open at all times!" the blonde man told his two 'colleagues' in fluent Russian. Both Mikhail and Yevgeny nodded, but remained silent, and then the three men made their way into the warehouse and the door was closed behind them. They were met by two Chinese man dressed in black suits and white shirts, but no ties. "We're here to see Mr. Ling" Hans said, as he held the handle of his briefcase with both hands.

"We know who you are!" one of the men said back in broken English, his face expressionless. "This way!" he then mumbled, gesturing past him.

"So much for pleasantries!" Hans quipped to his two bodyguards, who smirked a little.

As they walked deeper into the warehouse, the three men saw several more Triad members, all dressed in 'casual' suits and all armed with Scorpion sub-machine guns. A number of them were up on the second floor of the building, looking down. Hans and his associates soon saw a pristine office desk, which looked out of place in a warehouse, and behind the desk was sat a senior Triad member, 58-year old Wei Ling. It took a moment for Wei to acknowledge Han's arrival, and when he finally did...he looked at his watch, it was now 2:30am exactly. "Excellent timing Mr...?" Wei then said, pausing...

"Call me Hans!" the tall German smiled, as he glanced at his own watch. "I pride myself in arriving on schedule, otherwise what's the point of arranging a time?" he said.

"Very true my friend, very true!" Wei nodded, as he got to his feet, his English was perfect. "Please, take a seat!" he then offered, gesturing to a simple looking chair placed on the other side of the desk.

"I prefer to stand, thank you!" Hans responded politely.

"As you wish!" Wei sighed, as he glanced at one of his own, trusted bodyguards. "I take it you do have the 'merchandise'?" Wei then inquired, seeming a little eager to get his hands on whatever Hans was carrying.

A little smirk appeared on Han's face. "Of course!" he said, holding up his briefcase. "But I don't see the money!" Hans noted, as he purposely looked around. It was then that Wei clicked his fingers, and one of his men walked forward with a briefcase full of money, "$2 million as agreed!" Wei stated firmly, as the briefcase was placed on the desk and opened. Hans smiled again and then walked forward, somewhat cautiously. He placed his own briefcase on the desk and released the catches, opening it up and then turning it to face Wei. "Here's the merchandise, as agreed" Hans said, as he gestured to the 200 small plastic bags containing a white crystalline substance.

"So...this is the drug I've heard so much about?" Wei then mumbled, as he stepped forward and picked up one of the bags, holding it up to the light.

"Yes! A drug like no other" Hans smirked. "Also highly dangerous for first time users, roughly 50% of them die after taking the drug" he warned. "But I doubt that will influence your decisions very much" Hans then continued, knowing full well the Triads' reputation.

"Not really. You see all my men are absolutely loyal and willing to die for me anyway" Wei said, drawing Hans' attention to the armed men all around him.

"I'm sure they are!" Hans nodded, seemingly not impressed much. "And that concludes our deal" he stated, causing Wei to look up at him. He should have known that leaving the warehouse wouldn't be as easy as entering.

"One moment please. How do I know that this is actually the drug I want?" Wei asked, as he waved the little bag in the air. "It could be salt, or...simple cocaine! I know just how 'tricky' you Westerners can be" he then smirked. "I require a demonstration!"

Hans started chuckling, and turned back to look at his two bodyguards. "Yes I suspected you might" he then said, looking at Wei again, who wasn't laughing. Hans then slowly opened his jacket and got out his cell phone. "Luckily I have one all arranged" he grinned. He then dialed a number on the phone and starting speaking in Russian, obviously to more of his associates or bodyguards who were nearby. "This shouldn't take long!" Hans then addressed a nervous Wei, who was looking around. Suddenly, Wei's two most trusted bodyguards opened fire with their sub-machine guns, shooting the other Triad members. Caught by surprise...and utterly confused...the Triad gangsters were ripped apart by bullets, as Hans and his two bodyguards ducked out of sight.

With their sub-machine guns empty, the two Triad bodyguards then approached their 'master' and put their pistols to his head. Wei was shocked when one of them said something to him in Russian.

"I trust this was a good enough demonstration Mr. Ling?" Hans chuckled, as he stepped back into view, a little upset at having a few spots of blood on his suit. "Like I said, this concludes our deal" he said. After Hans then gave another order in Russian, the two Triad bodyguards put their pistols to each others' heads and killed each other.

Mikhail then grabbed the suitcase full of money off the desk, and the trio left the warehouse, leaving the bodies of ten Triad members littered throughout, and an angry...but unharmed Wei standing alone with his new stash of drugs. Once outside, Hans got on his phone again and congratulated his other two 'associates', Andrei and Vitaly, who had used the drug to possess the bodies of the two 'rogue' Triad bodyguards.

"That didn't take long at all" an 'amused' Hans remarked, as he got back into his Mercedes with his men and went off to rendezvous with Andrei and Vitaly, who by now would have returned to their own bodies in another car parked nearby.

152.content:
As Yevgeny drove back to the rendezvous point, a silent Hans in the backseat checked his watch again. 2:39AM. He breathed a sigh of relief that the ordeal was over with so quickly, and for once without a hitch. He had until the hour, perhaps he could have some fun before getting back to work. But even while Hans daydreamed about what to do after his success, one of his bodyguards was not so calm. Mikhail turned to look Hans levelly in the eyes, and clearly the man was surprised by the serene smile on Hans' face. In Russian, once again, Mikhail began: "Were you not worried that Wei would simply order you shot? I would like to think of myself as a skilled bodyguard, but when outnumbered 5 to 1 even I will doubt surviving. But you never even flinched once."

This broke Hans from his contemplative state, and the man slowly turned to look out the window. "I was never in any danger, Mikhail. Dust makes me invincible. There's no need to fear those who can't hurt you." Hans' deflection of the potential danger did nothing to sate Mikhail's curiosity, though. "But even with Andrei and Vitaly standing by with the drug, they could have killed you instantly before you could even signal them. I can't think of being more vulnerable than surrounded by an armed enemy." Hans turned to Mikhail and smirked, but said nothing. "This is not the first time you've tempted fate either. There's rumors that you've dealt with the Red Mafia." Hans simply kept smiling. "Oh really?" "Oh Yes. Said that you were selling the same drug to them as well." The grin on Hans' face only got wider. "And yet here I am, unharmed. A testament to my invincibility." Mikhail's face took on a hard look as he said the damming bit: "Those 'rumors' go on to say that they killed you once your business was done."

At that the smile on Hans' face melted away. A tense moment of silence passed between the two, and for a moment it look as if they were going to pull their guns on each other. But Hans simply began to speak, saying, "You're very well informed, Mikhail. I'll give you that. Tell me, do you have any regrets?" This clearly caught Mikhail off guard, as the man was silent for a few moments as Hans simply fiddled with his cigarette lighter. "No? None at all? Or simply not willing to tell me. That's practical, I suppose, but sadly it does mean that you go without a last request." A surprised look crossed Mikhail's face for but an instant before slight spasms rocked his body. Though the car began to swerve gently, Hans calmly put the lighter away and waited for the spasms to end.

A moment later, Mikhail regained his composure and looked straight at Hans. In perfect English this time, the man spoke, "So tell me, why did you hit the panic button this time Charles?" Briefly a look of annoyance crossed Hans' face, but he settled into a cool stare. "Hans has gotten too famous. Mikhail had figured out that he had died once before. Couldn't risk him putting the pieces together; we'll have to dispose of him." 'Mikhail' groaned a little and slumped back into the seat. "Damn it. It took weeks to find these two, you can't just keep killing off anyone who happens to stumble upon us." "No, we will do so. I'll not have this operation exposed because of little mercy for those caught in the crossfire. If they pose a threat, we eliminate it."

'Mikhail' said nothing, but simply glared at Hans as the car continued to drive along. From the front seat, Yevgeny turned his head slightly to address Hans, "What about the driver?" A moment of silence, then Hans responded. "He technically hasn't done anything, but he might have been listening to our conversation. We can't risk it, the lot of them will have to go. Might I suggest the nearby river?" 'Yevgeny simply nodded and made a sharp right at the next intersection, but instead of leading down a road it led off the bank and into the river. As the car sank beneath the water, the three of them simply sat still as darkness enveloped them. The three bodies weren't fished out for hours.
152.title: Following 'Hans'

1523.content:
Back at his desk in London, Interpol agent Ryan Smith, 36, was sat doodling on the piece of paper sat in front of him. He was normally busy but today was a slow day, everyone hunted by the organization was doing a good job of staying hidden from them. "Working hard as always?" one of Ryan's female colleagues smirked as she threw a newspaper on the desk.

Rebecca Knowles, 28, was a junior agent at Interpol, a bright young woman with wavy, shoulder-length black hair. Professionally attired in a dark grey trouser suit, white blouse and a pair of black high heels. What she lacked in experience she made up for with determination, and Ryan knew this. "Hey, doodling takes a lot of concentration" Ryan mumbled in response to Rebecca's acerbic statement, as he sat up straight.

"Hm, I bet it does!" Rebecca smirked. "Any news on Fredrico?" she then asked, referring to an international fraudster the two had been after catching for the last year or so. She seemed disappointed but not surprised when Ryan just shook his head. "Oh well, I'm sure he'll rear his ugly head some time" Rebecca said, trying to stay positive, then she walked off, her heels clicking on the floor as she went. Ryan watched his colleague walk away, cursing the fact that she was already engaged to her long-time boyfriend Chris. He liked Rebecca a lot, but he'd kept his feelings for her a secret. He sighed as he picked up the paper and glanced at the front page, then he started flicking through it. He stopped when he saw the article on Page 3: Bodies pulled from China river. The bodies of a German man and two Russians had been discovered in a car at the bottom of a river in Guangzhou, China. After reading the article, Ryan recognized the description of the German, tall, blonde, neatly groomed, immaculately dressed.

"Hey Becky, come over here a minute!" Ryan called out to his colleague.

"What now?" Rebecca answered as she sashayed over to Ryan's desk. Leaning over, a frown suddenly appeared on her face when she started reading the article. "You think its Hans Greschler?" she inquired.

"I'd say that's a good guess" Ryan nodded.

Hans Greschler was a known drug smuggler and murderer who was also on Interpol's list of wanted criminals. He was also very careful and good at what he did, which puzzled Ryan as to why he had died in a simple 'car accident' with two other men. "Contact Beijing, ask them for all the information they've got on this" Ryan politely 'instructed' Rebecca, who just nodded and picked up the phone.

Ryan just sat there, staring at the grainy picture of the car being dragged from the river. There was something 'wrong' about all this, and he was determined to find out what it was.

15233.content:
On a small, dusty dirt road in suburban China a small dated truck hurtled down the road. By all appearances, the rickety pickup truck was a piece of junk. Its red paint had faded away years ago, and the rust that now took its place made it look more brown than anything. Coupled with the sputtering engine and the plume of black smoke that trailed it, and you would think that its owner would have sold it for scrap years ago. Judging from the look on its three passengers in the cab, they most likely were contemplating such a move right now.

The driver was a man in his late 50s, and his salt and pepper hair was accented by the simple black baseball cap that sat upon it. While his button down shirt and chinos gave the impression of a traveling tourist, his cold demeanor seemed to suggest otherwise. "And you had the nerve to use my real name back in the car. What if there was a bug in there? Whatever happened to using our cover names, 'Vitaly'?" The driver cast a hard glare at the passenger sitting next to him. She was a woman in her late 30s, but if you were to simply look at her you would had never guessed. With her tight frame, youthful face, and long auburn hair, she looked to be a young beauty out for a little international fun. It certainly didn't hurt that her casual roll neck blouse accentuated some of her best features. "Well what can I say 'Hans', perhaps I was aggravated that our supposed expert negotiator had come close to blowing his cover. Again. At this rate, 'Andrei' might be better suited for this than you." She forked a finger at the passenger who occupied the window seat to her right.

'Hans' exuded an aged yet calculated intelligence, and 'Vitaly' carried herself with an apparent grace and finesse, but 'Andrei' just looked intimidating. The man was only in his early 30s, but with his large frame, shaved head, and hard facial features he looked like the kind of guy who had ended more lives than he could count. Even though he was dressed in a light flannel shirt and shorts, it did little to diminish the effect. "Will you two just stop bickering over this already? We completed the job, and no one is the wiser. Yeah, Charles fucked up. Who gives a shit, we still covered for him. Just drop it already Vanessa." At this, Vanessa threw her hands up in the air and turned her glare to him. "I'm sorry Tybalt, but I didn't join up to murder anyone who looked at me funny. I mean, gunning down Triad members is one thing, but murdering some mercenaries simply because you were sloppy? That's low, even by my standards."

At this Hans turned back to face her. "Enough! It's hard enough to drive this piece of junk without you preaching to us!" Vanessa returned a glare to Charles, but she remained a silent for a moment before continuing. "Fine. I won't preach. But on that note, why are we riding in this... thing? The Mercedes was much nicer than this." The engine stalled for a brief second before starting up again, as if to affirm Vanessa's statement. "Because that was tied to Hans Greschler, and with him dead we can't risk using any of his possessions. The last thing we need is some stupid beat cop to notice that we're driving the car of a dead man." Vanessa simply rolled her eyes and began muttering to herself, but she was denied even privately venting her muted apprehensions. Tybalt gently shoved her in the shoulder, saying, "If you have something to say, just say it. Don't bottle it up; it's unhealthy."

Her eyes gently drifted to Tybalt and a small smile crossed her face. "You know, sometimes I forget that there's a man buried under all that brawn. Fine. I'm just... oh, what's the word... aggravated that we have to keep literally killing most of our progress. I mean, back in St. Petersburg we took over that other weapons dealer... Grigori was his name, right? Small player, but he was a dead ringer look alike for Hans and it was easy to pass him off as the real Hans to the Red Mafia. Then when our 'expert' negotiator flubbed a few key facts during the deal, kill happy Charles here made us kill off all of Grigori's henchmen and the Red Mafia contact which, I don't need to remind you, lead to the death of Grigori. All in the name of 'no loose ends'. Then we had to spend weeks tracking down the real Hans so that the plan can continue. Now he's dead too, and we still have one more piece to complete. If we had just accepted that nothing goes according to plan, we could have been done with the entire op and be lounging on some Caribbean beach right now!"

Tybalt arched an eyebrow at Vanessa after her tirade, and simply inquired, "Done?" Vanessa took a few breaths, then broke into a full smile before responding. "Yes. And thank you, I do feel much better now." Tybalt simply shrugged returned to looking out the window while Charles responded to Vanessa's concerns. "You know that Grigori's death was not part of the plan. But when a plan revolves around secrecy, even the slightest ounce of truth can tear it asunder. We couldn't risk word of a fake Hans getting out, especially not to Wei or Myon, or else we'd be even worse off than we are now. The Red Mafia has the dust now, as does the Triad; who cares if some nobodies had to die along the way. Besides, we're only a few days drive from the border. One more job, then a quick trip back to China and we're home free. This will be simple, Hans or no Hans, fake or otherwise."
15233.title: Back with 'Hans'.

152332.content:
After hours of reading through case files and going through an entire pack of cigarettes, Ryan eventually began to piece things up, or...so he hoped. He had spent all night in the office and was a little worse for wear. He held up two pictures, one of Grigori and one of Hans, and a wry smirk appeared on Ryan's face. The resemblence between them was stunning and Ryan now knew he had to be on the right path. "Who's ballsy enough to screw with the Red Mafia?" he thought to himself. His train of concentration was then broke when the door to the office opened and in walked two of his colleagues, including Rebecca.

"Ryan?" she muttered in a concerned tone. "You said you were going to get some sleep. Have you been here all night?" she asked.

"Yep, but it hasn't been in vain, I'm making slow progress here" Ryan nodded in response.

"Christ, it smells like a pub in here!" Rebecca then complained as she wafter her hand through the haze of cigarette smoke in front of her. As she put her handbag down and grabbed a nearby air freshener, Ryan continued explaining to her what he had found. "Well...I'm glad my phone call to Beijing yesterday wasn't in vain, you any idea how hard it is trying to converse with a local who doesn't speak good English?" she chuckled.

"Yes I have!" Ryan mumbled, throwing Rebecca a glance.

"Of course you have, sorry!" Rebecca laughed.

"Look, we've got deceased members of the Red Mafia and a prominent mercenary...also dead. Either we've got a superhero crimefighter out there, or...there's some people who have their own agenda. Either way we've got to get out to China and follow up on this. I've already alerted the Chinese authorities that we'll be arriving soon. They've promised to cooperate fully with our investigation" Ryan explained, as Rebecca stood there, arms folded, and dressed in a light grey trouser suit, a white blouse and a pair of white heels.

"We?" Rebecca muttered.

"Yes...we! I need someone to carry my stuff" Ryan smiled.

"Oh...so I'm a personal assistant?" Rebecca said in her posh accent, arching an eyebrow in disapproval.

Ryan stood up and gave her another smile. "No, you're an intelligent, valued colleague...who could use a few more hours of experience under her belt" he told Rebecca, deciding to flatter her a little.

"Well...when you put it that way!" she smirked, pushing her hair behind her ears.

Ryan nodded, and after patting Rebecca on the shoulder, he started putting all the evidence into a single briefcase. "Now...I'm going to get a couple of hours sleep, then we're heading out, I'll meet you at Heathrow okay, I already booked us on a British Airways flight to Beijing" he said while yawning. "Oh...and don't forget your sidearm and your ID" Ryan said, as he set off towards the door.

"Oh...thanks for reminding me!" was Rebecca's acerbic response as Ryan disappeared out the door. "About time I got out of this dump" Rebecca said to herself, as she looked around the office. She then began to prepare for her trip to China.
152332.title: Ryan Smith catches a glimpse of the bigger pict...

choices: The trio continues their trip into North Korea.
1523321.content:
Taking a trip across China in a cramped truck was not exactly a pleasant experience. Having to ditch Hans meant having to ditch his resources as well, which meant that Charles, Vanessa, and Tybalt were left only what they could carry. While they were hardly without resources of their own, the People's Liberation Army's constant surveillance of all forms of communication meant that they were left no way to access them. Even without access to their funds they were far from unarmed though, as the constant rattle of four briefcases of dust in the back reminded them. It had taken them a little over a week, as they had to not only cross the country but also stick to the back roads to avoid prying eyes, but after many painful nights they had made it. The North Korean border was only a few miles away.

Tybalt was currently driving, and Vanessa was keeping him company while Charles was passed out between them. "So you really think that this will work?" Vanessa inquired to Tybalt. "I mean, I know that Charles said that arrangements had been made, but this plan seems to be full of holes." Tybalt in a quick low voice simply intoned: "Quiet, we're in view. Act the part." At this Vanessa's normally alert and spry demeanor settled in a suitably more lethargic one, and a sloppy smile crossed her face while her eyes unfocused. While Tybalt could not quite mimic the caliber of Vanessa's performance, to his credit his face was now colored a light red and he let out a rebel yell at the top of his lungs. They came to a quick stop in front of the border fence, and instantly a dozen rifles were trained on them.

A thin wiry man dressed in the North Korean military uniform approached the vehicle at a quick pace, shouting something in Korean in a loud but shrill voice. However, no indication of understanding crossed Tybalt's face as he simply continued to loosely smile and observe the guards. "I think we're, um... lost? Yeah, yeah, lost." He laughed a little at his comment, but the soldier did not seem amused. After shouting a few things to his men, he continued to talk in that irritably sharp voice, but this time in English. "I am Jungwi Du-Ho of the Korean People's Army! You are trespassing upon our sovereign soil! Identify yourself or we will treat you as foreign invaders!" At this Vanessa's head drooped slightly before bolting up again, and she slowly inquired in a low voice, "Hey Bradley, got anymore of that booze from the Chinese dude?" In kind, Tybalt responded: "No, no, we drank all of it, last night, at the furry bar... no... wait, it had tigers, not furries... golden tiger lounge, yeah yeah!"

With no indication, Du-Ho swung his rifle around and immediately slammed Tybalt in the head with the butt of it. A brief look of shock crossed Tybalt's face before he slumped over the driver's wheel with his eyes closed and did not stir again. Vanessa's head whirled as a terrified look of surprise crossed her face and she let out a scream that rivaled Du-Ho's own screeching. "As invaders of our sovereign territory, we now take you as prisoners of war!" He then shouted something to the other guards, and they immediately moved in to secure the truck and its cargo. While they moved the motionless forms of Charles and Tybalt across the border along with their possessions, a weakly struggling Vanessa shouted at the man. "No... no! We're... we're Americans, you can't do this shit to us! We'll SUE!" At this, Du-Ho simply slapped Vanessa in the face and locked the canister doors, leaving Vanessa alone in the dark compartment as the engine sputtered to life and started to move.

Vanessa had only the hum of the engine's motor to accompany her as she neatly organized herself from the entire affair. A triple knock from the driver's compartment stirred her from her busy work as she immediately went over to Tybalt and nudged him in the ribs. "Nice acting there. If I hadn't known any better, I'd have thought you actually went down." Tybalt simply grunted in response as he got off the ground and quickly took charge of the four briefcases. "Bastard." She started. "He's brilliant, but still a bastard." She lightly kicked Charles' unconscious form as if to drive the point home. "I understand Charles hitting you, but slapping me? Power tripping prick."
1523321.title: Back with Charles & Co.

15233212.content:
As Charles and his two 'colleagues' continued making their way through dangerous territory, Ryan and Rebecca were arriving in China after a very long flight. Once the plane had touched down, the two of them made their way off and were immediately confronted by a very strict Chinese customs official (a young woman) who lacked any kind of politeness. "ID!" the young woman demanded of Ryan...while at the same time scowling a little at Rebecca.

"Is this how you welcome all visitors?" Ryan grumbled, as he got his passport out, allowing it to be checked. Rebecca did the same and hers was snatched from her by the official, something that made her get angry.

Ryan could tell Rebecca was going to say something...so he got her attention and shook his head. "No!" he mimed at her.

"Agent Smith?" a man's voice suddenly said in broken english, causing the two Interpol agents to turn around. Before them stood two plain-clothed Chinese detectives, one was in his 40s and obviously a veteran, his name was Feng Yi. And beside him was a younger detective, also male, who was also taller, he was called Chuanli Po. "Yes?" Ryan responded, as the older man stepped forward to shake his hand. "I am Detective Yi, we have been assigned to assist you in your investigation into the deaths of the three foreigners" Yi said, remaining stone-faced much like the customs official.

Ryan knew full well that 'assist' actually meant 'being watched'. "Er...okay, that's fine! This is my colleague Agent Knowles!" he introduced Rebecca, but Yi did not shake her hand, instead he just nodded at her. "A pleasure!" Yi mumbled.

"If you'll follow us please, we will take you to the site of the accident" Yi said, as he and Detecive Po started walking off.

"Wait...what about the bodies?" Ryan questioned him.

"All in good time. They're being kept at the morgue in Guangzhou under police guard" Yi replied coldly.

Rebecca just frowned at the customs official as she returned her passport to her, then she rushed to catch up with Ryan, her high heels clicking rather clumsily on the floor as she went. "Why are these people so...rude?" she asked him, clearly annoyed.

"Communist state." Ryan shrugged. "Go figure!"

***


After a long drive to the sight of the 'car accident', they finally arrived. By this time the effects of the plane ride and and the road trip had taken its toll on the two British agents, they were really tired. "If you are too exhausted, we can do this tomorrow Mr Smith?" Yi suggested, for a moment seeming a tad concerned.

"No...no we might as well just have a quick look around, probably nothing to see here anyway since you've taken the car and the bodies away" Ryan replied, as he found himself unable to prvent a yawn exiting his mouth. He and Rebecca then stepped out of the vehicle and noticed the two armed police officers who were standing guard over the accident site. They began having a poke around, and the first thing Ryan noticed was how remote the area was, no witnesses to the crash. It was Rebecca however who noticed tire tracks quite some distance away, having wandered away from the others. "Hey Ryan, over here!" she shouted in her Kensington accent.

Ryan and the two Chinese detectives all walked over after locating her, and Rebecca pointed out the tracks. "Someone was here! Maybe they were waiting for our friends." she said, just poking around in the dark.

"Maybe!" Ryan mumbled, as he squatted down. "The tires must be worn, the treads aren't very deep" he then said.

"Whoever it is, they are probably out of the country already" Detective Yi suddenly interrupted, throwing a dampner on things. "Now...if you are ready to see the bodies?" he asked Ryan and Rebecca.

"Are there any buildings around here?" Rebecca asked the detective, who paused before replying. "Only an old warehouse, several miles down the road, not many people have a reason to come out here" he answered.

"Perfect place for criminal activities then I'd say" Rebecca smirked.

Detective Yi did not smile...
15233212.title: Meanwhile, back in China...

154.content:
"Is it done Ishikawa?" Masateru Sawamura, head of the Ando clan's Sawamura family, asked to the pretty young woman standing in front of him.

"It is." she stated simply, "Matsuyama will no longer be a problem."

"Hey, uh, so what's Rie doing here?" asked Daniel Martin. He wasn't fluent enough in Japanese to pick up on all of what was being said.

"I would like to know that myself." Masateru said before turning back to the woman. "Ishikawa, why did you bring Umeda here?" he asked speaking Japanese once more.

"I used the drug to hop into Matsuyama's body. Just a small amount, enough to get him situated by an open window. Once I started losing control of his body, I fell out the window. Luckily I ended up back in my own body before he hit the ground." the supposed Rie Umeda explained, "Umeda was in there as a witness. I took her in order to give a favorable story to the police and I'm stuck here for another few hours."

Masateru leaned back in his chair and groand, "And you thought bringing a hugely popular idol to a building housing the head of the Sawamura family was a good idea?" he asked.

"Umeda lives here as well in another apartment remember." she explained, "It won't raise any suspicions of ties to the Sawamura family and the Ando clan."

Masateru sat in thought for a moment. "You best hope it doesn't. That is not the kind of scandal she, and thus we, needs. Dismissed."

Daniel watched as the pretty pop star walked out of the penthouse apartment. "So, uh, what's going on here?" he asked trying to process everything.

Masateru turned back to him. "A bit of business." he said speaking in English, "You're aware of Shintaro Matsuyama, correct?" Daniel nodded; Shintaro was a well known producer for lots of big idol singers. "Matsuyama got into a bit of bad business with the Sawamura family. Gambling debts. We offered him a way to pay and he wouldn't play ball so now he's been eliminated." Daniel gulped. He'd heard stories that even if they were more "legitimate" the yakuza were still as ruthless as any mobster. "Then that is where you come in, Mr. Martin. You ran up a large amount of debt at hostess clubs run either by the Sawamura family or by... let's call them affiliates. Debt that you didn't have the money to pay." Daniel was starting to feel very uneasy. "Well we intend to have you pay, Mr. Martin." Masateru stated.
